statement.p:
Evaluate each of the following indefinite integrals, using the provided hints.
Evaluate \int \arctan(x) \, dx by using Integration by Parts with the substitution u = \arctan(x) and dv = 1 \, dx.
Evaluate \int \ln(z) \,dz. Consider a similar substitution to the one in (a).
Use the substitution z = t^2 to transform the integral \int t^3 \sin(t^2) \, dt to a new integral in the variable z, and evaluate that new integral by parts.
Evaluate \int s^5 e^{s^3} \, ds using an approach similar to that described in (c).
Evaluate \int e^{2t} \cos(e^t) \, dt. You will find it helpful to note that e^{2t} = e^t \cdot e^t.

li.p: \int s^5 e^{s^3} ds = \frac{1}{3} \left( s^3 e^{s^3} - e^{s^3} \right) + c .
\int e^{2t} \cos\left( e^t \right) dt = e^t \sin \left( e^t \right) + \cos \left( e^t \right) + c .

We use integration by parts with u = \arctan(x) and dv = dx. So du = \dfrac{1}{1+x^2}dx and v = x.
\int{\arctan(x) dx} \amp = uv - \int{v du} \amp = x\arctan(x) - \int\frac{x}{1+x^2} dx
For the integral in the last equation, use the substitution z = 1+x^2 and dz = 2x\, dx.
\int \arctan(x) dx \amp = x\arctan(x) -\int\frac{x}{1+x^2} dx \amp = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{z} dz \amp = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \ln(z) + c \amp = x\arctan(x) - \frac{1}{2} \ln \left( 1 + x^2 \right) + c

Using u = \ln(z) and dv = dz, we obtain du = \dfrac{1}{z} dz and v = z. So
\int \ln(z) dz \amp = z \ln(z) - \int dz \amp = z \ln(z) - z + c

Using z = t^2, we obtain dz = 2t dt and \dfrac{1}{2} dz = t dt. So
\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt \amp = \int t^2 \sin(t^2) \cdot t dt \amp = \int z \sin(z) \frac{1}{2} dz \amp = \frac{1}{2} \int z \sin(z) dz
Now using integration by parts with u = z and dv = \sin(z) dz, we obtain du = dz and v = -\cos(z). So
\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt \amp = \frac{1}{2} \int z \sin(z) dz \amp = \frac{1}{2} \left( -z \cos(z) + \int \cos(z) dz \right) \amp = \frac{1}{2} \left( -z \cos(z) + \sin(z) \right)
Finally, we use z = t^2 and obtain
\int t^3 \sin(t^2) dt = \frac{1}{2} \left( -t^2 \cos\left(t^2 \right) + \sin\left(t^2\right) \right) .

Use a substitution with z = s^3 and dz = 3s^2 ds.
\int s^5 e^{s^3} ds \amp = \int s^2 s^3 e^{s^3} ds \amp = \frac{1}{3} \int z e^z dz
Now use integration by parts with u = z and dv = e^z dz. So du = dz and v = e^z.
\int s^5 e^{s^3} ds \amp = \frac{1}{3} \int z e^z dz \amp = \frac{1}{3} \left( z e^z - \int e^z dz \right) \amp = \frac{1}{3} \left( z e^z - e^z \right) + c \amp = \frac{1}{3} \left( s^3 e^{s^3} - e^{s^3} \right) + c

Using z = e^t, we see that dz = e^t dt and so
\int e^{2t} \cos\left( e^t \right) dt \amp = \int e^t \cos\left( e^t \right) \cdot e^t dt \amp = \int z \cos(z) dz
In Example, we saw that
\int z \cos(z) dz = z \sin(z) + \cos(z) + c . Combining these two results, we obtain
\int e^{2t} \cos\left( e^t \right) dt \amp = \int z \cos(z) dz \amp = z \sin(z) + \cos(z) + c \amp = e^t \sin \left( e^t \right) + \cos \left( e^t \right) + c
